justifications: Jamie Dimon has a message for Brexit Britain: There is nothing wrong with changing your mind.
Dimon said before the June 23 referendum he thought Brexit would be a 'terrible deal for the British economy.'
Dimon is not the only one suggesting Britain could still reverse course.
Asked by an Italian newspaper how the European Union should now respond to the vote, Dimon said it must work together to address its weaknesses.
Europeans should say: look, there are rational complaints, we are going to fix them for all of Europeans, not for Britain alone, but for everyone else.
Maybe you can even reverse Brexit.
Some voters have already said they regret their decision, especially after leading Brexit campaigners back-pedaled on a number of pledges they made.
Dimon was one of many Wall Street executives who supported Britain staying in the EU.
JP Morgan has 16,000 staff in Britain, but may have to move some employees out of the country because of Brexit.

On Thursday, Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank of America (BAC) issued a joint statement, promising to work with the U.K. to help London 'retain its position as the leading international financial center.'
London banks will pay the 'price' of Brexit
